With your help, Abduzoir will be able to buy additonal cows and improve the cattle’s feed. Let’s work together so that Abduzoir can make his dream a reality.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Aydee Rosaria

texts.es:
Aydee es socia del Banco Comunal Legioncito.
Aydee es conviviente, tiene 37 años y 2 hijos, Aydee se dedica a la elaboración de empanadas, postres variados, que prepara en su casa con la ayuda eventual de sus hijos, sus postres los hornea en un horno alquilado.
Aydee necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar y harina.
Los sueños de Ayde son tener una panadería, brindarles a sus hijos todo lo mejor.
texts.en:
Aydee is a member of the Communal Bank Legioncito. She is 37 years old, lives with her partner and has 2 children. Aydee makes pies and desserts, which she prepares in her home with the occasional help from her children, and then she bakes them in a leased oven. Aydee needs a loan of 800 soles which she will use to buy sugar and flour. Aydee dreams of having her own bakery and providing the best for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cereceda, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Aydee needs a loan of 800 soles which she will use to buy sugar and flour.

loans.name: Armando

texts.es: Armando tiene 54 años, vive solo. Trabaja ofreciendo el servicio de fotocopiado y  escritura por computadora desde hace 8 años, para ello arrendó un local que se ubica en la carretera principal de su comunidad, siendo una zona comercial y donde todos sus vecinos acuden para solicitarle sus servicios, de esta manera  Armando tiene los ingresos necesarios para  seguir adelante. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo en MFP y se compromete a ser puntual en la devolución de su préstamo. Solicita este dinero para reparar y dar mantenimiento a su computadora y a su fotocopiadora.
texts.en:
Armando is 54 years old and lives alone. For the past 8 years he has owned and operated a photocopy and computer business. Armando rents a space on the main street of his community, because it is a commercial area and is a location which all of his neighbors pass during the day. In this way, Armando earns the income he needs to be successful. This is the first time that Armando has asked for a loan from MFP and he promises to return it on time. He is asking for this money to repair his computer and photocopy machine.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair computer and photocopy machine

loans.name: Chanta Arame

texts.fr: Chantal Arame T., 49 ans, mariée, 01 enfant et 04 autres en charge est membre du banc villageois de Ngueen depuis 1 an et demi. Elle veut  un prêt pour renforce  son activité de vente de boissons en bouteille et canettes. Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Chantal Arame T., age 49, is married and has a child, plus four others to look after. She has been a member of the village loan group Ngueen for a year and a half. She wants a loan to bolster her business selling bottled and canned drinks. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in beverages

loans.name: Helenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Helenda T.,46 years old, is married and a resident of Mansabay Bajo, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. Her husband is a fisherman.The fish caught by her husband are sold at the public market or to their neighbors. Because they want to buy additional materials for fishing like fishing nets, they both agreed to request a loan through Paglaum MPC in the amount of 10,000Php.

Aside from the financial assistance they have received, they have also enjoyed other benefits like insurance, etc. Mrs. T. believes that with Paglaum's help and her patience and hard work, she will be a successful vendor someday.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for fishing

location.town: Plaridel-Mansabay Bajo Lopez Jaena Misamis Occiden

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian A. is a 36-year-old mother of 5 children who are in school. She is very hardworking and resourceful for her family. She trades in charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. Vivian obtains her supply of charcoal from Afram, where she lives, and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of charcoal to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to pay her children’s educational fees, as that has been her priority. She belongs to the village bank called Choice.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal

loans.name: Jesus Es Prosperidad Group

texts.en:
“Jesus es Prosperidad” is a group of 10 women entrepreneurs seeking their third loan from Esperanza International, Kiva's partner. The group’s past two loans have been successfully repaid, and the group hopes to utilize additional loan funds to further business expansion and allow for additional profits.

Angela is one of the coordinators of this group in the city of Santiago. Angela, mother of four married children and grandmother to nine grandchildren, operates clothing sales from her home and throughout the streets of Santiago. She declares business is well and Dominicans love to buy clothing. Angela’s past loan performance demonstrates a commitment to her goal of improving the life of her grandchildren and providing for their physical needs.

Other members of Angela’s microfinance bank run similar entrepreneurial activities including food, clothing and variety sales.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase Clothing to Sell

loans.name: Sugran Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji is the wife of N. A. who lives in a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 9 years. Sugran baji operates a clothes-sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. Sugran baji’s husband belongs to a sanitary supplies-selling business with experience over the past 6 years. Sugran baji is applying for a loan to buy supplies (pipes & taps) to sell.

She is the group leader for five other women from her locality. Shamshad baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Salma baji want a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Najma Kosar baji wants a loan to buy decorative items to sell. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy sanitary supplies for re-sale

loans.name: Honorata

texts.en:
Honorata A. earns a living for her family by selling RTW (ready-to-wear) clothes. She is a widow and has seven children. Without the support of a husband, she wants to gain income to support her family. Previously, she bought seashells for a living, but she has found that selling used clothing in the flea market is more profitable and interesting.

She is asking for a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more items like clothes to sell. She is also interested in venturing into other lines of business to augment her family's income.

CEVI is reaching out to more people, especially the poor, to help them start and maintain their own businesses. They give credit, training, and insurance coverage to all their clients to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her RTW business.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela tiene 44 años es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su propia casa y lo que más desea es salir adelante. Graciela tiene un negocio muy divertido, vende peluches en las ferias de Puno y Juliaca, ella es una vendedora muy hábil y siempre consigue la forma de venderle algo a las personas que concurren a su puesto, a quienes trata con mucha cortesía y siempre les brinda una sonrisa.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes y aconsejarles sobre los peluches que puede comprar, lleva 5 años en esta actividad y lo que menos le gusta es tener que vender bajo el inclemente sol, ya que esto la cansa mucho, espera más adelante tener su tienda donde pueda vender sus peluches con más tranquilidad. Este es el primer préstamo de Graciela en MFP, está muy feliz por la oportunidad y desea pagarlo a tiempo ya que quiere acceder a otros créditos posteriormente, en su banco comunal es una socia muy activa. Con los mil nuevos soles de préstamo, Graciela comprará más peluches para tener mas mercadería que vender.
texts.en:
Graciela, 44, is a hard-working woman. She lives in her own house and what she wants most is to get ahead in life. She has a fun business, selling stuffed toys in the markets at Puno and Juliaca. She is a skillful saleswoman who knows what approach will work best with each prospective customer, all of whom she treats with courtesy and a smile. The thing that she most likes about her job is talking with prospective customers and advising them on which stuffed toy they should buy. She's operated the business for 5 years and the thing that she likes least about it is working in the hot sun, something that completely exhausts her. She hopes to one day have her own shop where she might sell her stuffed toys more easily. This is Graciela's first MFP loan. She is very happy for the opportunity and wants to repay the loan on time so that she can have the chance to borrow again in the future. She's an active member of her community bank. With the S/.1,000 (one-thousand new soles) loan, Graciela will buy more stuffed toys so that she has plenty of merchandise to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy stuffed toys to resell.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok T. is 44 years old and a married woman. She currently lives in Kompong Cham Province where she earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house, raising them for their offspring and for slaughter. She has been running her business for years. Her husband's name is Phon (shown in the photo), age 50, who works with her business raising pigs. Beside the pig-raising, they also cultivate rice during the farming season.

The couple has five children who are single. Two of their children are employed: one daughter is a garment worker in Phnom Penh City and one son is a local farmer. Sok T. will use all the loan to purchase feed and piglets to raise and to support the entire farming business.

loans.use: To purchase feed and piglets to raise

loans.name: María Auxiliadora

texts.es:
La señora María Auxiliadora L. se dedica a su negocio de venta de pan en su establecimiento en la ciudad de Chinandega donde a diario comercializa el pan y también ofrece gaseosas a sus clientes.

Actualmente, ella ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito para la compra del pan y las gaseosas y así suplir la panadería y brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Señora María Auxiliadora L. is devoted to her business selling bread in her establishment in the city of Chinandega where every day she sells bread and also provides soft drinks to her customers. Currently she has turned to CEPRODEL with the objective of requesting a loan for the purchase of bread and soft drinks so that she can stock up her bread shop and provide a good service to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bread and soft drinks.

loans.name: Cerrito Group

texts.en:
The committee named Cerrito was formed on March 24th, 2008, thanks to the director of the group, Mrs. Antoliana Fernandez, who works as a saleswoman. She talked to a loan officer about forming a group and then gathered 18 women. The group works well together and is now on its fifth cycle with the Fundación. 

This is an excellent group thanks to the solidarity they have. Each woman invests her loan in her respective business. All of the women participate in other activities to save money as a group and to mutually help each other achieve goals they have as individuals and with the Fundación Paraguaya. The committee participates in weekly meetings and is extremely supportive. 

  1  Antoliana F. - Handicrafts sales 
  2  Cantalicia Q. - Avon cosmetics sales 
  3  Liduvina C. - Food sales 
  4  Felicita C. - General store 
  5  María Z. G. - Broom sales 
  6  Brígida S. - Food sales 
  7  Rumilda Vázquez - Clothing sales 
  8  Ladislaa P. - Lottery ticket sales 
  9  Sadi S. - Chicken sales 
10  Antonia S. - Fruit sales 
11  Josefa M. - Fruit and vegetable sales 
12  Analía Q. - Fruit sales 
13  Marisel E. - Food sales 
14  Adelaida G. - Dressmaker 
15  Fidelina O. - Diner 
16  Francisca Z. - Clothing and shoe sales 
17  Silvia M. - Beverage sales 
18  Idalina F. - Fruit sales

loans.use: To purchase materials for handicrafts

loans.name: Latif

texts.en:
L. Latif has run a livestock business for many years. He has used the proceeds from his business to support his parents because he is not married and has no children yet. Since he began his business, he has worked hard to use his earnings to sustain his home, and his livestock business has helped him to achieve his goals. Currently, Latif needs to purchase more livestock in order to expand his business. Intelligently, he is seeking a loan from IMON International in order to acquire additional animals to offer in markets.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth K., 27, is married and lives with three children in the Battambong province. She is engaged in the sewing business, making US$ 3 each day, while her husband (pictured) operates a motor-taxi by providing his services at the local markets, making about US$ 5 each day.

A financial crisis has played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these difficult times, Muth K. is asking for a loan of US$ 700 to invest in the agriculture sector. She wants to grow fruit trees and various kinds of vegetables on her own plot of farmland in the hope that she will be able to generate additional revenue for her children's education and family use.

loans.use: growing fruit trees

loans.name: Laurice

texts.en:
Laurice E. is from the village of Maningcol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Laurice is married and has 1 young child. To make a living, Laurice rents rooms to college students. Laurice has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Laurice joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laurice has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Laurice is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Laurice from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.es:
La señora Adelaida R. tiene ya más de quince años dedicándose a la venta de ropa usada y nueva esté negocio es la fuente de ingreso para su familia ya que tiene dos hijos adolescentes que quiere darles un estudio profesional. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para comprar más mercancía ya que tiene poca y quiere invertir en ropa de invierno ya que viene la temporada y quiere estar preparada con suficiente mercancía, y así tendrá más ingreso a su familia y a al negocio, que con las ganancias planea pagar el crédito.
texts.en:
Adelaida R. has been selling used and new clothing for over 15 years. This business is the source of income for her family. She has two adolescent children. She would like to give them the education to become professionals. She is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise because she does not have much. She wants to buy winter clothes because the season is approaching. She wants to be prepared with sufficient merchandise. That way she will have more income for her family and her business. She plans to pay the loan with that income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim S., 36, is a garment factory worker and resides in the Phnom Penh with her husband and two of her children. She typically makes US$3 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a motor-taxi driver who makes US$3 per day as well. Due to the difficult of leaking roof, Mrs. Sim is asking a loan of US$1200 to fix it.

loans.use: To fix the leaking roof.

loans.name: Adela's Group

texts.en:
Adela A. is a young hardworking wife who strives to be able to help her husband improve their family's living conditions, to save for their children’s futures and to fix their home. She and her husband, Arman have four young children who range from two to four years in age and the family lives in the village of Tabao Rizal. San Enrique, Negros Occidental. 

Adela is 39 years old and has established herself as a skillful entrepreneur for almost 10 years since she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999. When she got her first loan, she invested it in food vending of Native Ilonggo delicacies such as "bayi-bayi" and "kalamayhati" which are made of rice flour, whole brown sugar and coconut milk.Over the years, her food products have become quite popular in the community to the point where the increased demand has required her husband to help with production and delivery. Larger loans made it possible for Adela to establish a networking business as well. Her income has grown to an average of PHP 10,000 per month, which has enabled her to fix her dilapidated house and set aside some savings for her children's future .Adela's products taste so good that it was selected by NWTF's Client Services Department to be one of the sugar-based products it featured in a week-long trade fair that it organized in August at SM City Bacolod, the biggest mall in Negros Occidental.  Her products were so well received by the mall shoppers that it she will be offering them again in the trade-fair rerun at SM City Bacolod this October during the Masskara Festival, which is a famous tourist event in the island.  It is expected to be one of the best and fast selling products in the trade fair.She borrowed PHP 19,500 for her previous loan and used it as additional working capital for her food vending and networking business. That loan was fully paid on time. For her next 14th cycle loan she wants to borrow the same amount of PHP 19,500 which she intends to use again as additional capital for her native foods vending and networking business.Adela is shown in the picture posing with some of the networking products that she sells.About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to have additional working capital.

loans.name: Silvia María

texts.es:
Silvia María es una mujer dinámica y perseverante, vive en el distrito D. Manantay región D. Ucayali, tiene 49 años, es madre D. tres hijos D. los cuales uno es mayor D. edad, el cual la apoya, ya que ella es separada desD. hace mucho años del padre D. sus hijos.
Se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes al por menor, tiene su bodega en su casa y también se dedica a la crianza y venta D. pollos. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al 2000” desD. hace ocho años, donD. siempre ha demostrado ser una socia puntual. El primer crédito que recibió fue para invertir en artículos para su bodega.  En la actualidad Silvia necesita un crédito D. 3000 soles, con el cual comprará productos para su bodega (arroz, detergente, leche, azúcar, etc.) y alimento balanceado para pollos. La meta D. Silvia es tener un locutorio ya que su casa se encuentra ubicado lejos del centro D. la cuidad y las personas no tienen mucho acceso a la comunicación telefónica.
texts.en:
Silvia María is a dynamic and persevering woman. She lives in the district of Manantay in the Ucayali region. She is 49 years old and is mother to three children, one of whom is adult and supports her since she has been separated from the father of her children for many years. She is dedicated to selling groceries at retail prices. She has a shop in her home and she is also dedicated to raising and selling chickens. She has been a member of the "Mujeres al 2000" Community Bank for eight years, where she has always demonstrated that she is a punctual member. The first loan that she received was to invest in items for her shop. Currently, Silvia needs a loan of 3,000 soles with which she will purchase products for her store (rice, detergent, milk, sugar, etc.) and balanced feed for her chickens. Silvia's goal is to have a phone store since her house is located far from the center of the city and people do not have a lot of access to telephone communication.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products for her store and balanced feed for her chickens.

loans.name: Tsendjav

texts.en:
T. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two young sons in Kharhorin, the ancient Mongolian capital city. Her husband is currently unemployed and stays home with the two boys. T. operates a clothing retail business at a local market. She began her business in 2005 after working as a herder with her husband for several years. Her business has been quite successful and has allowed the family to buy land and build a house on it. She hopes to keep growing her business so that she can provide for her family in the future and improve their quality of life. T. is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to import clothes from China for her business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To import clothes from China for her business

loans.name: Dorila

texts.es:
Dorila  es una mujer perseverante y activa, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 49 años, madre de cuatro hijos, de los cuales uno es mayor de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes al por menor, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que trabaja en la municipalidad Provincial de coronel Portillo. Dorila forma parte del Banco Comunal “Pan de vida II” desde hace tres años, el primer crédito que recibió fue para invertir en la compra-venta de gaseosas. 
Con este crédito de 2000 soles, comprará productos para vender en su bodega como arroz, azúcar, fideos, etc., ya que recién esta empezando con este negocio y necesita surtirlo. El sueño de Dorila es tener una tienda bien implementado, con artículos para toda ocasión.
texts.en:
Dorila is a perseverant and active woman. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 49 and has four children; one is an adult. She sells retail groceries. She has help from her husband, who works in the Provincial de Coronel Portillo municipality. Dorila has been a part of the Pan de Vida II Communal Bank for three years. She used the first loan that she received to invest in buying and selling soft drinks. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy products like rice, sugar, and noodles, etc. to sell in her convenience store. She has recently started in this business, and she needs to stock it. Dorila’s dream is to have a well equipped store with items for every occasion.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to sell in her convenience store (rice, sugar, and noodles, etc.)

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Z. Grace is twenty-nine years old and is married with four children: two girls and two boys. She resides in Agip Cell, Uganda. Grace is running a retail grocery store and a salon in her area of residence and she is a farmer, too. She is using the loan to expand her business by purchasing retail items such as cooking oil, soap, salt, and sugar. Her future hope is to expand her business to generate a high income for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as cooking oil, soap, salt, and sugar

loans.name: Martha Carolina

texts.es: La señora Martha Carolina,  tiene 44 años de edad, es madre soltera con dos hijos,  uno de ellos cursa el cuarto año de secundaria el otro tiene 27 años de edad. Martha tiene un negocio de venta de cosméticos, Este negocio empezó hace 4 años con muy poco capital  de trabajo, como una búsqueda de fuente de ingresos alternativos ya que además ella imparte clases en colegio público  Ella empezó vendiendo muy pocos cosméticos, después fue que empezó a invertir un poco más,  El crédito será invertido en la compra de lápiz labial, brillo, estuches de sombra y estuches de vanidad. Por lo que se acerca la época navideña y la señora desea invertir y comprar ahora que están un poco bajos los precios. Su meta es llegar a tener un una tienda de artículos variados que pueda estar ubicada en el mercado, que brinde las facilidades económicas a ella y a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Martha Carolina is 44 years old and a single mother with two children. One of them is in his fourth year of secondary school, and the other is 27 years old. Martha has a cosmetic sales business, which she began four years ago with very little working capital, in search of an alternative source of income, since she also gives classes in a public school. She began by selling just a few cosmetics. Afterwards, she started to invest a little more. This credit will be invested in the purchase of lipstick, polish, eyeshadow cases, and vanity boxes. Since the Christmas season is approaching, she wants to invest and buy now, while the prices are a little lower. Her goal is to eventually have a store with various items, that could be located in the market, which would provide economic facility to her and her two children.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for her business

loans.name: Santos Estela

texts.es:
la Sra. Santos Estela A. tiene 40 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos,  de los cuales 1 ya se graduo del colegio y dos de ellos se encuentran estudiando, Santos vive en el barrio Morazan de la ciudad de Nacaome. Tiene una pulperia desde hace 4 años y medio y esta ubicada en su casa de habitacion.
Santos necesita el credito para surtir mas su negocio, ya que es su unica fuente de ingresos y con este negocio sale adelante con sus hijos, cubre los gastos del hogar. ahorita necesita tener mas ganancias ya que esta teniendo mas gastos del hogar.
nos comento que se siente muy feliz porque gracias a su negocio esta educando a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Santos is forty years old, married, and has four children, one of whom has already graduated from high school and two of whom are studying. Santos lives in the Morazan neighborhood of the city of Nacaome. She has had a grocery store for four and a half years and she runs it from her home.

Santos needs the credit to supply her business, since it is her only source of income and with this business she improves things for her and her children and covers the household expenses. Right now she needs more profits since she is facing greater household expenses.

She told us she feels very happy because, thanks to her business, she is educating her children.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy candy, churros, razors, spices, tortillas, beans, butter, margarine, oil, bulbs, batteries, biscuits, coffee, soap, pepper, sanitary napkins

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 39-year-old married woman with five children aged between 18 and 25 years, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a three-roomed house where she lives with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets two meals a day.

Jackline owns a fish stall and works in Naguru, a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty-five customers a day, selling to all categories of people both wholesale and retail.

Jackline incurs transport costs to and from buying fish from Gaba landing site but her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges are the transportation of fish from Gaba to her stall in Naguru, seasonality which makes her business difficult, and the rainy season which disturbs her a lot because she works in an open place.

Jackline has been in her business for ten years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her seventeenth loan working with the same group members. Jackline joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women at the village level.

Jackline wants to use this loan to buy more fish. She is hoping to see her business grower bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her stall

loans.name: Rosa Angelica

texts.es:
la señora Rosa Angelica F. P. tiene 51 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Manuel Gutierrez, quienes son pareja desde hace mucho tiempo.  Su familia es cristiana protestante.
Sus hijos estan en la universidad y dependen de ellos. 
Rosa se dedica al comercio desde hace 10 años y don Manuel (su esposo) tiene un negocio de abarroteria. Les va muy bien en sus negocios. 
Rosa esta solicitando el credito para comprar calzado para escuelas y colegios, se aproxima la epoca escolar y las ventas son muy buenas. 
 
su anhelo es que su hijos se graduen de la universidad, sean buenos profesionales y hombres de bien.
texts.en:
Rosa Angelica F. P., 51, is married to Manuel Gutierrez; they have been a couple for a very long time. The family is Protestant. Their children are in the university and still depend upon them. Rosa has been a merchant for 10 years and her husband, Manuel, has a grocery store. They do well in their businesses. Rosa is asking for funding to buy school shoes; the new school term is near and sales are very good. Her dream is that her children graduate university, become good professionals and upstanding citizens.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school shoes.

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr:
cette femme exerce depuis 1990 le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale,elle exerce ce commerce dans sa propre boutique et s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, sa clientèle  est composée de toutes personnes et aussi d'étudiants et d'écoliers, elle se fait aider par une personne voulant agrandir son stock, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'une dizaine de pâte alimentaire, une quinzaine de boîte de conserves et des légumes
elle est mariée et mère de  enfants c'est avec le revenu de son commerce qu'elle  contribue aux dépenses du foyer
texts.en:
This lady has sold a variety of food products since 1990; she has her own shop and sources her goods from the large market at Lomé. She has one assistant. Her customer base is varied, and includes students and schoolchildren. In order to enlarge her range of stock she is seeking a loan from WAGES; she would use this to buy a dozen lots of pasta, and a dozen jars of jam and vegetables. She is married with children, and uses the revenue generated by her business to see to her family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of various food products

loans.name: Ivon

texts.en:
Ivon is a 35-year-old woman living with her husband and 3 children in the town of Dickwella, in the Matara district of Sri Lanka.  Her husband works as a day laborer, and their three children (ages six, seven, and twelve) help Ivon in her business after they return home from school.  She started her business one year ago, and is a very active woman, so naturally she likes to work hard.  Coir making consists of extracting the fibres of coconut shells to be woven together, often into string, yarn, ropes, or floor mats.  It is a very popular trade in Sri Lanka.

Ivon is seeking a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC to buy more coir to process and sell to her currently-expanding base of customers.  She attributes the success of her business to hard work and a good location.  But ultimately, she hopes to relocate her business to another area and start her own shop there.

loans.use: to buy coir

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is widowed with nine children. Four of her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Jane takes care of her grandchildren. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Jane owns a stall selling fruits and vegetables in Kitawuluzi. Besides this vegetable business, she also sells weaving work (including mats and tablecloths) and foodstuffs at her stall.  She works seven days a week. Jane receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Jane has been in this business for 26 years and her business challenges include seasonality. She has been with MCDT for a few years, servicing her third loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more baskets of fruits and vegetables and meters of cloth for weaving tablecloths. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and get money to construct her own house. She joined MCDT because she could access loans with no collateral with trusted women.

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables and fabric

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic U. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 29 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Marivic owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products such as viand in the local community. Marivic has been involved in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. Marivic is requesting a new loan, her third, of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Melenaite

texts.en:
Melenaite L. is 50 and married with 4 children.  She owns a business venture, selling food products in the local community.  Melenaite has many years of experience in this business.  Melenaite  needs a loan of WST $2250 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 750 talas or US $313 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Melenaite  joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Melenaite 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bernarda

texts.es:
La señora  Bernarda  se dedica a vender  productos de mercería y librería , esta actividad lo realiza caminando por los alrededores del barrio donde vive ,  sale todas las mañanas bien temprano a comprar y luego  repartir de acuerdo a los pedidos  , tiene  buena clientela  formada ya que a esto se dedica hace 15 años y gracias a este trabajo logro mantener siempre a sus cuatro hijos hoy en día todos mayores de edad.
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra de sabanas, hilos, cuaderno, lapices, telas y otros artículos para su mercerías.
En el futuro desea mucho ampliar su negocio y para ello debe  comprar un vehículo para repartir sus mercaderías,  pero cree que con el esfuerzo y el trabajo logrará concretar sus proyectos.
texts.en:
Señora Bernarda sells sewing supplies and school supplies in the streets of her neighbourhood. She leaves the house very early every morning to make her purchases and then deliver them to the customers who have made the orders. She has a good customer base as she’s been doing this work for fifteen years. With the money she earns, Bernada has always managed to support her four children who are now grown up. She is asking for a loan to buy bedding, thread, notebooks, pencils, fabric etc. In the future she would very much like to expand her business, and in order to do that, she would have to buy a vehicle to make deliveries. Bernada believes that with hard work and effort, she will manage to do this.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, notebooks, pencils etc

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
As they say, determination leads to destiny, and M. Fred is gaining momentum in his charcoal-selling business. Many people tend to undermine casual work but the 57-year-old married father of two children and two dependents has been able to earn a living through that business for twelve years.

Charcoal is commonly used here in Uganda as a form of energy in many homes that cannot purchase paraffin (kerosene), gas or electricity. Through the selling of charcoal Fred is able to earn 250,000 Ugandan shillings monthly as profits, though having drawbacks like transporting his products to bigger markets such as Kampala city.

With this loan, Fred hopes to expand into bigger markets. He says that he inherited his business from his father after his father’s death and works hard to ensure that he expands it further.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell to expand his business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is married with five children, and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Mariam owns a ladies salon and works upon all categories of hair ranging from plaiting, gelling, and relaxing. Besides this salon business she also sells maize bran. 

Mariam rents her business premises at 55,000/= for the salon, and 100000/= for the shop where she sells maize bran. Her customers are mainly women. Mariam buys cosmetics and hair relaxers from shops on Luwum street, Kampala city, and maize bran from Owino market. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of relaxers and weaves.

Her major business challenge is that of transport, because she uses public transport to and from shopping. She aspires to build her own shops. Mariam joined MCDT to acquire more capital for her business. Mariam resides in and owns a three roomed house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of hair relaxers and weaves.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda G. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Upper Cogon Bago, Compostela, Cebu Province. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a bairan (tool-sharpening) business and a general store. Her husband Ritchie G., who is 30 years old, helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are from 4 to 12 years old.

Yolanda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon five years ago because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past seventeen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, uplifting her family's standard of living.

This time, for her 18th loan, Yolanda is borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use to buy more tools and equipment for her tool-sharpening business so that she can continue to save to attain her dream to have a shop in the local market.

Yolanda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy more tools and equipment for her tool-sharpening business

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel C. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 30 years old. Liezel is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a specialized-retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice, grains, and vegetables in the community. She also sells  bottled gas/petroleum. Liezel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Liezel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liezel is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Liezel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Saina

texts.en:
Saina F. is 34 and married with five children (ages 2 - 16).  She owns a business driving a taxi.  Saina has two years of experience in this business.  Saina needs a loan of WST $1,500 to renew her vehicle license.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Saina joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Saina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To renew her vehicle license

loans.name: Grace Anyango

texts.en:
Grace Anyango O. is 51 years old and comes from Siaya district. She is a widow and has three children who are school-going, aged 18, 20, and the last born four years old. 

Grace sells kerosene and has been in this business for three years. She is applying for a loan of Kshs 15,000 which she intends to use to buy several gallons of kerosene. This is her third loan that she is accessing from KADET LTD after successfully completing the previous ones.  She will use the profits made to cater for the family needs and pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to diversify into other businesses in the future.

loans.use: To buy gallons of kerosene to add to her stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seafood as well as fuel and nets for the fishing vessels.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda M. is married and lives in Brgy. 8, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: Used Clothing and Ready-To-Wear (RTW) businesses. 

Imelda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Imelda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to buy more inventory for her business so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs and be able to sustain her business with her own revolving capital. Imelda M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her business

loans.name: Agueda Candelaria

texts.es:
En los Arenales de la parroquia Crucita cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal 6 de Julio. Este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas, que son muy visitadas por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros,  ofrece diversidad de lugares hermosos y una rica variedad de platos típicos de la región.

La señora Candelaria es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal, ya son 19 ciclos que ha realizado sus créditos en esta institución y esta muy a gusto por aquello ya que según dice es el único lugar donde realiza sus créditos sin tantos requisitos. Tiene 54 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y tiene seis hijos mayores de edad, con ella vive un nieto de 9 años que es como su hijo. El esposo ya no trabaja es jubilado.

Tiene una tienda de víveres de consumo,  trabaja  todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 20h00, dice que no le incomoda vender hasta  más tarde ya que tiene su negocio en su casa, vende de todo desde productos de primera necesidad hasta bebidas alcohólicas y tarjetas telefónicas, trabaja con la ayuda de su nieto y su esposo, sus productos los compra en Portoviejo.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar mercadería para surtir más su tienda.
 
Sus sueños son ver que su nieto sea un buen profesional y seguir creciendo cada día más.
texts.en:
In Arenales in the church Crucita every fifteen days the communal bank 6 de Julio gathers. This location is known for its beautiful beaches, which are visited by many tourists, both national and international. It offers a diversity of beautiful locations and a rich variety of typical regional meals. 

Candelaria is the founding member of the communal bank. Already they have completed 19 loan cycles with this institution and she is very comfortable with that because according to her it is the only place which completes their loans without too many requirements. Candelaria is 54 years old, is in a civil union relationship and has six grown children. She lives with a grandson who is 9 years old and is like her son. Her husband doesn't work as he is retired.

She has a store with food supplies and works every day from 6am to 8pm. She says that it doesn't inconvenience her to sell her products so late because her business is in her house. She sells everything from basic necessities to alcohol and telephone cards. She works with the help of her grandson and her husband and she buys the products in Portoviejo. 

She will use this loan to buy merchandise to supply her store.
 
Her dream is to see her grandson become a good professional and to continue growing every day.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, eggs, meat and general supplies.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 20 year old single man from Chtoura. Since 2007, he has been working as a tractor and diesel mechanic. He has 12 years of experience. Ali is requesting a loan for the first time from A. Majmoua in order to buy necessary tools for his business. Ali would like to by a "balango" which is a machine used to move tractor engines and parts from one place to another to make maintenance easier. He also would like to buy new mechanic tools. 

Ali's clients are farmers, friends, and neighbors. He loves his work and has been working with machines since he was eight years old and helping his parents with the family income. Ali hopes to expand and improve his workplace as much as he can. He is still young and believes he can work hard and do his utmost to become the best.

loans.use: To buy necessary tools for his business

loans.name: Lilias

texts.en: Lilias Y. is currently in the business of selling fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. Lilias is 40 years old. She is married and her husband is a businessman. She has 4 children and 2 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Giovanni

texts.es:
Giovanni B. F., tiene la edad de 34 años, está casado y tiene 1 hijo que es su mayor prioridad. El quiere comprar unos cerdos para aprovechar la oportunidad que le brinda su suegro de prestarle una porqueriza que tiene desocupada,  cuenta con mucha experiencia ya que siempre ha trabajado en esta actividad. Con ésta opción  puede mejor sus ingresos  y trabajar en su propio negocio y así tener una mejor calidad de vida tanto él como su esposa y su hijo. Piensa en el futuro de su hijo y poderle dar estudios para que en un futuro sea un buen profesional.
Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. El  no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Giovanni B. F. is 34 years old.  He is married and has a child who is his main priority.  He would like to buy some pigs to take advantage of the opportunity which his father-in-law is offering him in lending him a pigsty which is standing empty.  He already has a lot of experience since he has always worked in this activity.  With this option he can improve his income and work in his own business and thereby provide a better quality of life for himself, his wife and his son.  He is thinking about his son's future and would like to make sure he is able to study so that he can become a good professional in the future.

This is Giovanni's first loan from FUDECOSUR.  He has not had any previous loans from state banks but FUDECOSUR has given him this loan on easier terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: To buy pigs

loans.name: Selma

texts.en:
Selma V. is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating one business venture: buying & selling bananas.  She lives in Brgy. Ipilan, Brookes Point, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her buying & selling of fruits business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.  

Selma is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her fruit vending business.   This will be her 23rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Selma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund fruit vending business

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Some people tend to complicate things, but for Merlita D. P., 44, life couldn't be simpler. Being a CCT* community partner of Talon, Amadeo, Cavite, Philippines, Merlita employs simple but effective principles to make her business grow. She is the wife of Orlando, a laborer, and is a mother to two college students.

Merlita owns a sari-sari (variety) store in her neighborhood, where she sells items that are daily needed by people in her community. When a neighbor immediately needs a bottle of vinegar, a sachet of toothpaste, or some biscuits to eat, Merlita is ready to offer her merchandise. She also sells electronic load for mobile phones. Monthly, she earns around Php10,000.

To help her grow her business, Merlita is requesting for a Php20,000 loan. This is one simple way of energizing her business--adding to the array of items she has in her store to attract more customers with more options and to further meet their needs. She believes that with this loan money, she can undoubtedly increase her profits and make her store grow.

One challenge Merlita faces recently is the number of customers who do not pay their debts. She is also challenged by competition in the neighborhood, since many households in the Philippines put up a small sari-sari store to augment the family income. However, Merlita believes that challenges can be met by simply having faith in the Lord and exerting her best effort. She does not give up, because she knows that soon, the days will be brighter for her, both in her personal life and in her business. Just like any other parent, Merlita's simple dream is to see her children finish schooling.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Purchase of grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Sopheak

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheak L. (pictured here) is 23 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Sokchea Sorm is 25 years old. They have been married since 2009 and have no children yet. They live with his parents and brothers and sisters along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sopheak is a motorcycle taxi driver. His wife is a garment factory worker. He hopes to change his business from motorcycle taxi to Tuk Tuk (a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi), because it could carry more goods and people than a motorcycle taxi. 

He asked for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a Tuk Tuk.

loans.use: To purchase a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with four children (two boys and two girls) all of whom attend school.  She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she has runs a school which contributes to her other source of livelihood.  Eunice faces a major challenge of seasonality.  During the rainy season the demand is lower compared to the sunny dry season where the demand for goods is high.  She hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the 30,000 KES loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking oil.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María, es una mujer tierna y dedicada, de 69 años. Es separada de su esposo y vive en compañía de su hija mayor y sus nietos, en su casa propia. Con los que juntamente tratan de salir adelante. El trabajo al que se dedica María, es la venta de productos nutricionales hace 15 años, pero en la actualidad también vende agua purificada, que los comercializa por vasos, ya que tiene la propiedad de bajar de peso, por eso es que tiene más clientes mujeres que varones. Actualmente se encuentra en temporada de verano, por lo que su negocio tiene buena acogida, siendo así que hizo instalar este aparato regulador en su casa. Lo que más le gusta  de su negocio; es la orientación que brinda a sus clientes, ya que conversando se distrae mucho. Por ello tiene pensado en el futuro diversificar su negocio, comprándose una maquina de coser, para realizar sus sueños frustrados, como el de ser costurera y arreglar prendas de vestir. Ella pertenece al grupo comunal de pocos integrantes, y esté es la 8vo crédito que tiene con  MFP, demostrando compromiso y comprensión con los integrantes de su asociación. María, con el crédito que solicita, comprará su maquina de coser y pagar sus cursos de confecciones y de ese modo aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
María is a very loving and devoted woman of 69.  She is separated from her husband and lives in her own home together with her eldest daughter and grandchildren.  Together they try to get ahead in life.

María has been selling nutritional products for 15 years.  She also currently sells purified water by the glass.  The water has the effect of lowering weight which means that she has more women as customers than men.  It is currently summer which means that her business is very popular.  For this reason, she installed this machine in her home.  What she most likes about her business is the guidance that she gives to her customers since she really enjoys chatting to her customers.

In the future, María plans to diversify her business, buying a sewing machine so that she can realize her frustrated dreams of becoming a seamstress and mending clothes.  She belongs to a community bank with few members and this is her 8th loan from MFP.  She has displayed commitment and understanding towards the members of her group.  María will use her loan to buy a sewing machine and pay for some dressmaking courses.  In this way, she will increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and sign up for a dressmaking course

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
From Phnom Penh City, Phan S. is 29 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than five years. He and his wife sell fish that they buy from their wholesale supplier. He is married to Keo Sengheng, 26, who works at selling fish with him also. 

Besides this work, Phan S. has also been planting a rice crop as his annual business. Phan S. is looking for a $500 loan as capital to support his farming business. He will use the loan to buy a cow to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To buy a cow to plow the farmland

loans.name: Horm

texts.en: From the province of Kompong Cham, Horm S. is a 29 year-old married woman and mother of three young children. She and her children are shown in the photograph. Horm S. has made a living for many years by cultivating a rice crop on her farmland. Her husband is a recycling seller--he travels around his village to buy used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The products which he buys are leftover electricity wires, cans, and bottles. Horm S. is looking for a loan to purchase a good piece of farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Sixty-year-old Fely is a married woman living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She raised her children in the same town.

Fely is a farmer. She cultivates her land for planting and harvesting rice crops. Fely sells her harvest to her town's market. She says it is easier to sell rice than other crops because it is a main Filipino food.

Fely requested a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs. In the future, Fely wishes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Housam

texts.en:
Housam is a 26-year-old single man who owns a bakery. He lives in Tyre and opened his shop in 2007. His bakery is in front of the general hospital; therefore, his customers are hospital patients, employees and neighbors. He offers very affordable prices.

This is Housam's third loan. He reports that the previous ones helped him support his business, which in turn allowed him to build his own house. Housam is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to reinforce his sales by increasing his stock of flour and oil. He also wants to finish building his house. In the future, Housam wishes to open a new branch and to help his brothers by hiring them at the bakery.

loans.use: to increase his stock of flour and oil and to pay for house maintenance

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAN MARTIN DE ZURITE”; Este banco está ubicado en el Poblado de Zurite,  provincia de Anta y  departamento de Cusco.

La Sra. Marina, es viuda y tiene 76 años de edad,  tiene 4 hijos y 9 nietos; la socia nos comenta que ya sus hijos son independientes y que ella desea continuar en el grupo de bancos comunales porque esto la mantiene ocupada y le da fuerzas para continuar trabajando y viviendo, ella es una mujer muy alegre y de buen sentido del humor, la socia tiene como principal actividad la agricultura y aunque en la actualidad los hijos y nietos le ayuden a sembrar y cosechar las tierras de cultivo, ella sigue siendo participe, la socia también cría animales menores, ella cría chanchos, cuyes, pollos, la socia está en el grupo desde el inicia, cuando este grupo se formo se hizo las reuniones en su casa y actualmente lo siguen haciendo aquí, la socia tiene 12 años en el banco como miembro activo, ella desea invertir el préstamo en la compra de alimento para sus animales, y aumentar pollos y cuyes. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de animales menores y alimento.

La socia valora y agradece el préstamo otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas de forma disciplinada.
texts.en:
Marina C. B. is a member of the village bank, “San Martin De Zurite." This bank is located in the village of Zurite in the Anta province of the department of Cusco.

Marina is a 76-year-old widow. She has four children and nine grandchildren and she tells us that her children are already independent. Marina wants to keep participating in the village banking group because it keeps her busy and gives her the strength that she needs to keep working and living. She is a very happy woman and has a good sense of humor. 

Marina mainly works as a farmer. Currently her children and grandchildren are actually working alongside her to plant and harvest the crops on her land. She also raises small animals such as pigs, guinea pigs and chickens. Marina has been in the village banking group since the beginning. Back when the group was formed, she would hold the meetings at her house and this is where they are still held today. Marina has been an active member of the group for 12 years now. She plans to use the loan to buy feed for her animals and to purchase more chickens and guinea pigs. She would like to purchase more small animals and animal feed.

Marina appreciates and is grateful for the loan that has been awarded. She promises to be very disciplined about making her payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase small animals and animal feed.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda works hard to support her family. Yolanda is married and has a cheese-making business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy some materials for her cheese-making business. She has been 20 years in this business.

In the future, Yolanda would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and ingredients for her cheese-making business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 30 years old and is a married woman with a 7-month-old child. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

Rebecca got engaged in farming twelve years ago. Now she helps her husband maintain their farm. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. Rebecca does her best to help provide for the family. She joined CEVI, a KIVA partner, and applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP. She plans to use it to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. Rebecca hopes for their harvest to increase.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en: Carolina is a married woman with three children. She is 51 years old and has had a food selling business for six years. Carolina sells fruits and vegetables to the people in her community. She has been in this business for six years. She is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 to purchase additional vegetables to sell, such as cabbages, tomatoes, squash and onions that would help to increase the capacity of sales for her business. In the future, Carolina hopes to have a big business and increase her income to provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell such as cabbages, tomatoes, squash and onions.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 50 years old. She is married and has seven children, all of whom are currently in school. Catherine has a poultry farm business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Catherine has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Catherine hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda, 55, is a married woman with three children. For five years she has sold frozen foods such as longanisa, tocino and hotdogs to the people in her community.

Yolanda is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy the raw ingredients needed for her food processing and sales. She hopes to use this loan to maintain her business and provide for her family’s needs.

loans.use: to buy the raw ingredients needed for her frozen food processing and sales.

loans.name: Rodgers

texts.en: Rodgers is a 33-year-old Ugandan man who needs a loan to buy timber and bananas to sell. He is from Kyenjojo district and is married with four children aged between 13 and 6 years. He lives in a semi-permanent house with 6 people and his dream is to educate his children and buy land to farm. He deals in timber and banana trading and got his start-up capital from growing beans and maize. He is faced with the problem of banana price fluctuations. In future he wants to acquire machines to cut timber and start up a carpentry workshop.

loans.use: To buy timber and bananas to sell

loans.name: Maria Yessenia

texts.es: Yesenia de 25 años es madre soltera tiene un hijo de 8 años inicio su negocio hace 5 años vendiendo ropa para dama cabaleros y miños y gracias a la ayuda de su familia que le han apopyado mucho y tambien a sus clientes que se han incrementado considerablemente,y gracias a eso sus ventas a subido, por eso ella esta solicitando este credito para la compra de ropa en bariedad. y surtir sus ventas,el sueño de ella es darle un mejor futuro a su hijo.
texts.en: Yesenia, age 25, is a single mother with one 8-year-old child. She started her business five years ago, selling clothing for women, men and children. Thanks to the help of her family, who have supported her greatly, and to her customer base, which has grown considerably, her sales have increased. For this reason, she is requesting this loan for the purchase of a variety of clothing. This will increase her sales. Her dream is to give her child a better future.

loans.use: to purchase varied clothing.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is 67 years old and married to Jacinta. They are blessed with eight children. John has been a farmer for the past 20 years and earns a monthly income of 3,000 KES, which he uses to support his family. He is applying for his fifth loan from Kiva partner, KADET. He will use the loan to buy seedlings, spraying chemicals and watering pipes. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will boost his farming business. His hope is to educate his children up to university level.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, spraying chemicals and watering pipes.

loans.name: Guadalupe Del Carmen

texts.es: Guadalupe del Carmen de treinta y ocho años de edad vive con su compañero de vida y sus cuatro hijos. Ella posee una tortillería y pupuseria la cual es muy conocida por las personas del lugar, pues sus tortillas son las mejores de la zona y las pupusas tienen un sabor inigualable, las hace de chicharron, queso y frijoles ó al gusto del cliente, el lugar es higiénico y los precios bajos, además el servicio que brinda Guadalupe es excelente; como toda mujer trabajadora su labor la ha extendido a vender también productos de belleza pues su sueño es ver crecer su negocio, y con ese entusiasmo que la caracteriza es como se decidió a solicitarle a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar materia prima como maíz, queso, chicharrón, frijoles entre otros. Guadalupe del Carmen tiene fe que su duro trabajo le permitirá llevar a su hogar seguridad económica y una vida mejor.
texts.en:
Guadalupe del Carmen is 38, and lives with her life companion and their 4 children. She has a store where she makes tortillas and pupusas (stuffed corn tortillas). It is well known by local people, since her tortillas are the best in the area and the pupusas have a flavor that is beyond compare.  She makes them with shredded roast pork, cheese, beans, or to the client's taste. Her place is hygienic, the prices are low, and Guadalupe provides excellent service.  

Like many a hard-working woman, her work has expanded, and now she also sells beauty products, as her dream is to see her business grow. With her characteristic enthusiasm she decided to ask INTEGRAL for a loan that will allow her to buy corn, cheese, roast pork, beans and other things.

Guadalupe del Carmen has faith that her hard work will allow her to provide her family with financial security and a better life.

loans.use: To buy corn, cheese, roasted pork, and beans.

loans.name: Ventura

texts.es:
La señora Ventura tiene la edad de 48 años, estdio hasta quinto de primaria, se encuentra casada con el señor Cristino que trabaja de campesino, ellos tiene 2 hijos los cuales estudian. ella vive en una zona cañera.

Ella nos platica que desde hace unos años decidio iniciar con su propio negocio de venta de pollo porque vio que la economia esta casa vez mas dura y no alcanza con lo que gana su esposo es por eso que decidio hecharle la mano a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.

Doña Ventura realiza sus ventas 3 veces por semana, se levanta muy tempranos a limpiar el pollo, y despues afuera de su casa pone una mesita, sobre la mesa pone el recipiente de pollo para despues esperar a sus clientas para la preparacion de sus alimentos.

Ella necesita este credito para la compra de pollo en pluma, bolsas de plastico para la venta de sus productos.

Doña ventura espera que con esta inversion su negocio prospere y pueda ofrecerle a sus hijos una profesion en un futuro.
texts.en:
Ventura is 48 years old and studied until fifth grade of elementary school.  She is married to Cristino who works as a farmer.  They have 2 children who are in school.  She lives in a sugar cane zone.

She tells us that a few years ago, she decided to start her own business of chicken sales because she saw that the economy was becoming more and more difficult and what her husband makes wasn't enough to cover expenses.  For this reason, she decided to lend her husband a hand with the household expenses.

Doña Ventura makes her sales 3 times per week, rising very early in the morning to clean the chicken.  Later, she sets up a table outside of her house, upon which she places the container of chicken, waiting for customers for the preparation of the food.  

She needs this loan in order to buy chicken and plastic bags for the sale of her products.

Doña Ventura hopes that with this investment, her business will prosper and she will be able to offer her children a professional future.

loans.use: to sell chicken

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past two years, Winnie has been working hard to manage her salon, where she does hairdressing for local women. 

To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids and will help Winnie to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Winnie hopes that in the future she will be able to own a retail shop. 

Winnie is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Winnie who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids.

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima is the treasurer of this group. She is 40 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has a daughter and a son; her daughter studies at school and her son is preschool age (under seven). Fatima works as a bookkeeper in the Department of Agriculture. 

Eight years ago she saved 10,000 soms from her salary and purchased a calf for breeding. Since that time she has been breeding cattle to make additional money. She sells milk products, and in this way earns an additional 1500 soms per month. With money received from the loan Fatima will purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future she plans to start building a shed to keep cattle. 

---Where Did This Loan Come From?---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line–People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.
